section.title: Upgrading (to) &name-icinga;

note.para: If you are using &name-idoutils; then you have to update it, too. Please take a look at upgrading_idoutils as well.
If you are using &name-web; then you have to update it, too. Please take a look at upgrading_icingaweb as well.

section.para: During development there may be cases where the handling of bugfixes might touch the userspace. We try to avoid this as far as possible but sometimes it is inevitable.

If there's a new &name-icinga; version available on &url-icinga; you should consider updating. Newer versions contain bugfixes, minor or major, which makes it even more important to get the latest and the greatest. If you already installed &name-icinga; using the quickstart guides it's rather easy to install newer versions. It's also possible to perform that without root privileges by doing an install from source. It highly depends on your likings.
Make sure you'll have a safe backup of your &name-icinga; installation and configs. If anything goes wrong you can restore your old setup rather easy.

Regular updates of &name-icinga; are possible just by re-installing &name-icinga;. Please keep in mind that configure requires the same parameters as before - look it up in config.log and store that in a safe location.

Become the icinga user. Debian/Ubuntu users might use sudo -s icinga. $> su -l icinga Get the latest Icinga version from &url-icinga; and extract it. Then run configure like you did with the old version. #> ./configure --with-command-group=icinga-cmd --enable-idoutils Compile the source. #> make all Please make sure that you don't overwrite your configs - always make a backup! Don't use make install-config and/or make install-webconf if you want to manually diff the config files. #> make install install-base install-cgis install-html install-init install-commandmode install-idoutils or decide what you want to upgrade by just typing 'make' which shows all available options. Check your config and restart Icinga. #> /etc/init.d/icinga checkconfig #> /etc/init.d/icinga restartThat's it!
There was a small misspelling bug in &name-icinga; 0.8.0 resulting in archived logfile names beginning with a capital "I" like in 'Icinga-$date'". This was fixed in version 0.8.1. and newer.
If you experience this problem then please use the following script to fix the file names
section.programlisting:
#> cd /usr/local/icinga/var/archives
for oldfilename in `find ./ -name "Icinga-*"` do newfilename=`echo $oldfilename | sed -e 's/Icinga/icinga/g'` mv $oldfilename $newfilename done
section.para: We try to be compatible with the configuration files of the current &name-nagios; 3.x versions so there should be very little you have to do to "upgrade" from &name-nagios; 3.x to &name-icinga; &ver-icinga;. Assuming you've already installed &name-nagios; from source code as described in the &name-nagios; quickstart guide, you can install &name-icinga; quite easily.
If you are upgrading from &name-nagios; 3.0.x you might need to install PHP:
Use Yast to install the packages php5 and apache2-mod_php5 or use zypper
Make sure you have a good backup of your existing &name-nagios; installation and configuration files. If anything goes wrong or doesn't work, this will allow you to rollback to your old version.
Please install &name-icinga; according to the quickstart guide. Please note that

listitem.para: the default prefix has changed to "/usr/local/icinga"
the environment macros start with ICINGA_
PNP4Nagios is aware of that since 0.6rc1 (2009.09.20) but the macros are needed in "sync" mode only.

check_multi includes support since v0.21 (2010.06.03), but you have to rerun the installation using 'configure --with-nagios_name=icinga' so that check_multi contains the correct values. You can use the option "-s" instead to set certain values.
the configuration file names of the (enhanced) IDOUtils are named idomod.cfg/ido2db.cfg instead of ndomod.cfg/ndo2db.cfg

section.para: Become the icinga user. Debian/Ubuntu users might use sudo -s icinga.
Get the latest &name-icinga; version from &url-icinga;
Extract the tarball and change to the directory just created
Start the &name-icinga;-configure-script with the options you used the last time with &name-nagios;. You'll find the call in the file config.log. Example:
Compile the &name-icinga; source code.
Install the programs, documentation, classic web interface and the init script. Your existing config files will not be overwritten.
section.screen: #> make cgis #> make install #> make install-cgis #> make install-init
section.para: Instead of using "make install-config" copy your configuration files from <Nagios-path>/etc/ to <Icinga-path>/etc/. Before starting &name-icinga; you have to alter some things:

listitem.para: The filename of the main config file has changed from nagios.cfg to icinga.cfg. #> mv nagios.cfg icinga.cfg should be sufficient to change that

You have to edit the main config file (icinga.cfg) to change the directives named "nagios_user" and "nagios_group" to "icinga_user" and "icinga_group" respectively. Depending on the paths you're using you may have to change them as well.
You have to edit the CGI config file (cgi.cfg) to change the paths you're using.

section.para: Copy other relevant files from your &name-nagios; installation to the new location. If you are unsure about the path then please have a look at nagios.cfg and/or icinga.cfg.

listitem.para: retention.dat (it contains certain status information, comments and other "sticky" stuff)
nagios.log (rename it to icinga.log)
archives/nagios-<date>.log files (&name-icinga; is able to process both nagios-<date>.log and icinga-<date>.log files so you don't have to rename the files)
You don't have to copy status.dat and/or objects.cache because these files are recreated during startup. Please recreate objects.precache before startup if applicable instead of copying it

section.para: Verify your configuration files, correct errors (if any) and start &name-icinga;.
That's it - you're done!
Please keep in mind that

listitem.para: the URL has changed to http://localhost/icinga/ (for the classic UI)
the name of the admin user has changed to icingaadmin

section.para: It shouldn't be too difficult to upgrade from &name-nagios; 2.x to &name-icinga; &ver-icinga;. The upgrade is essentially the same as what is described above for upgrading from &name-nagios; 3.x releases. You will, however, have to change your configuration files a bit so they work with &name-icinga; &ver-icinga;:

listitem.para: The old service_reaper_frequency variable in the main config file has been renamed to check_result_reaper_frequency.
The old $NOTIFICATIONNUMBER$ macro has been deprecated in favour of new $HOSTNOTIFICATIONNUMBER$ and $SERVICENOTIFICATIONNUMBER$ macros.
The old parallelize directive in service definitions is now deprecated and no longer used, as all service checks are run in parallel.
The old aggregate_status_updates option has been removed. All status file updates are now aggregated at a minimum interval of 1 second.

Extended host and extended service definitions have been deprecated. They are still read and processed by &name-icinga;, but it is recommended that you move the directives found in these definitions to your host and service definitions, respectively.

The old downtime_file file variable in the main config file is no longer supported, as scheduled downtime entries are now saved in the retention file. To preserve existing downtime entries, stop &name-nagios; 2.x and append the contents of your old downtime file to the retention file.

section.para: Also make sure to read the "What's New" section of the documentation. It describes all the changes that were made to the &name-icinga; code since the latest stable release of &name-nagios; 3.0.6. Quite a bit has changed, so make sure you read it over.

If you currently have an RPM- or Debian/Ubuntu APT package-based installation of &name-nagios; and you would like to transition to installing &name-icinga; from the official source code distribution, here's the basic process you should follow:

listitem.para: Backup your existing &name-nagios; installation
Configuration files
Main config file (usually nagios.cfg)
Resource config file (usually resource.cfg)
CGI config file (usually cgi.cfg)
All your object definition files
Retention file (usually retention.dat)
Current &name-nagios; log file (usually nagios.log)
Archived &name-nagios; log files (usually nagios-<date>.log)
Uninstall the original RPM or APT package
Install &name-icinga; from source by following the quickstart guide
Restore your original &name-nagios; configuration files, retention file, and log files
Verify your configuration and start &name-icinga;

section.para: Note that different RPMs or APT packages may install &name-icinga; in different ways and in different locations. Make sure you've backed up all your critical &name-nagios; files before removing the original RPM or APT package, so you can revert back if you encounter problems.
